name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 19/ If you've made it all the way to here, there's one more thing. Something new is on its way... -//t.co/dKNKdWsqRy @hikeapp

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 18/ These principles are a part of a set of broader values that we call The Hike Code' which is our culture document. One day hopefully soon we'll publish the whole thing.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 17/ Applied to our un-bundling, things start becoming very clear. It's the reason we're not unbundling Hike News & Content. It also becomes clear the move(s) we're making in Gaming that led us to invest in WinZo (and not build ourselves).

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 16/ The simpler the principles, the more you're on point. This is a great filter not just for us but for anyone launching something new. The more points that check off the higher the probability of success of a project.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 15/ The principles: 1. Is the problem/market big? 2. Do we have a unique perspective on it? 3. Can we truly be Customer Obsessed? 4. Less is More (Opposite SuperApp) 5. Compete only on our strengths 6. Can we have super fast product Iteration? 7. Do we like the business model?

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 14/ As a result we now have a set of principles that we use to make decisions on what opportunities we jump in to. Think of principles as a decision making framework (and an incredible way to scale culture). Here they are:

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 13/ So in the interest of being thoughtful we had to ask - Was it un-wise to launch payments in the first place? How could we avoid being in such a situation again?

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 12/ If we do it right, this allows us to "make big bets without betting the company". That's how we do things.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 11/ "Business is like baseball with one difference - A home run is 1 run but in business a success can yield a 1000 runs." So @hikeapp we swing for the fences and we swing big, as long as: 1. We're 'thoughtful' 2. The 'cost of striking out is low'.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 10/ A metaphor I first heard from Jeff Bezos that I loved and adopted and tell our teams regularly: "In baseball the best batters with highest batting average hit more home runs but also have higher strike out rates. So they're incentivized to swing for the fences."

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 9/ At hike, we are constantly innovating. Reality is sometimes innovations don't work out and that's ok in the long term as long as you're learning rapidly from everything you do.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 8/ Today, we have a 'high-stakes poker game' going on between 4 massive balance sheets with no clear winner in sight: Walmart (PhonePe) Amazon Alibaba/Ant (PayTM) Google (GPay) Looking back cutting payments was one of the wisest choices we made.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 7/ Fast forward a few years, payments in its current form' as a business model in India is a big ?. At best, it's a loss leader but my god what an expensive one.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 6/ 4 months in, we realised that the probability of success of the project was quite low and it was a game we would not win. So by the end of 2017 we cut payments and we moved on.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 5/ contd.. 3. Regulation uncertainty at the time around KYC was brutal making innovation difficult 4. On the cusp was also UPI which if worked would commoditise this entire space

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 4/ A few things became clear to us quite quickly: 1. Scale came fast but not without incentives. This was going to be a big capital sink. Cashbacks with no end in sight. 2. In an open market like India anyone with a ton of capital could jump in. Distribution was no moat.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3/ We had sizeable scale at our peak (10m+ DAU) and given that distribution, within a month after launch we were doing 3 million transactions / day (mostly recharge, some % of bus bookings etc).

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 2/ We launched payments in mid-2017 to a lot of excitement. It was our way to start building a business model on Hike the SuperApp.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 1/ One of the wisest decisions we made in recent years was to cut payments from our overall strategy. Here's a tweet storm talking through some of the thinking behind this (and more).

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @shantanukd @asana @Superhuman Being productive is both streamlining time with others and also time for thinking. If you don't do that tough to get time carved out for thinking (focus time). Then there's what you think about? - the backlog and how do you think? which is problem solving. Equally important.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @kageman @asana @Superhuman Zero interruptions

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3 ways I've 100x-ed my productivity last 18 months 1. Designed my calendar to take control of my time 2. A todo list to jot down things on the fly = backlog for my focus time' @asana (literally a 2nd brain) 3. Simplified email for incoming items unplanned in 1 & 2 @superhuman

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @MotwaniSuhas So you want people with a certain Grit, Resilience and high degree of Optimism. Those can be screened out quite easily.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3/ When you're building something new, this is all that matters. Strategy, tactics, plans will all evolve, they are meant to in a world changing so fast. At the end of the day a great company = great people.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 2/ As you scale beyond 100, be mindful of assumptions like these, they can make your grip slip on who enters the door. Screening for this trait is so important. These people exist but you have to work hard to find them. You gotta find them and surround yourselves with them.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 1/ One of my biggest mistakes while building @hikeapp was to assume that everyone we hired wanted to be the best version of themselves. It's quite the idealistic mindset and I learnt the hard way that isn't true.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: A feedback framework that's worked wonders for me: 1. Just an Opinion: Feedback is just an opinion, consider it but finally 'Your Call'. 2. Strong Suggestion: Take feedback seriously, do some in depth research but finally still 'Your Call'. 3. Mandate: Must do. 'My call'.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 5/ Lastly, there's been little innovation in this space in the last decade. Mostly incumbents using their distribution to copy. That's likely discouraged many people. But maybe that's more room to innovate? We're excited

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 4/ Looking through history of this space, we've seen every new generation build on the advancements in tech and culture. The new products looked nothing like what existed at the time. In the near future, things like "changing DPs" and even the "feed" will feel very antiquated.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3f/ Newer Business Models All of the above will give rise to newer business models, ones that will put the customer at the centre. Unlikely to be ads in the traditional sense. Think some form of transactions (micro-transactions, virtual goods, subscriptions etc)

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3e/ Consumers as Owners It's a bit strange that consumers aren't part of the value chain. Turning customers into owners is a fascinating idea and a potentially disruptive one. The technology to do that is emerging quite quickly.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3d/ Vertical Communities We don't live our lives in one massive community. We're specific in the activities we engage in (art, gaming, fitness etc). Would be no surprise that these networks would be naturally smaller in size. Some great examples @FortniteGame , @peloton, @whoop

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3c/ Self worth shifting online faster than ever 40% of people's waking life is now spent on their smartphones. The next generation is far more comfortable online than offline. This is truer in emerging markets where social norms are still catching up.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3b/ Bits are cheaper than Atoms We don't control atoms but we do bits and morphing them is efficient, cheap and quick. One can now bring richer experiences that people enjoy at the top to the masses, faster and cheaper and also in new and novel ways via the virtual world.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3a/ Advancements in Technology: - Rise of 4G adoption - Good smartphones across all prices - Big strides in AI: Machine Learning, NLP, Vision & more - Seamless payments & more trust - The rise of crypto and blockchain This has opened the door for tremendous innovation

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 2/ In a world that's evolving so quickly it's strange that social products still feel the same (we're still using products invented in the 2G era). It feels like the right time for the next generation of social products to be created. Here are 6 principles driving our thinking.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 1/ Some thoughts on the future of social. I just posted a new blog post: "The Rise of Social Niches" -//t.co/xkhYm443f9 Summary in the tweets below.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: "If you always put limits on everything you do, physical or anything else, it will spread into your work and into your life. There are no limits. There are only plateaus, and you must not stay there, you must go beyond them." - Bruce Lee

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: Intelligence = knowledge. It is built by gaining information from external sources. Intellect is the faculty to think, to reason, to decide, to be original. It can't be gained externally, only developed yourself with effort. The intellect is unique to the human species.

text: Just broke a 20-hour fast. Things get easier post 15-hours. I've been intermittent fasting almost daily for over a year (12-15hrs/day). Pushing longer on some weekends. No better way to reset body long-term. Just put less in and let the nature take care of the rest.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: To your watch, an hour always means exactly the same thing, regardless of whether you are solving a problem or or hitting the gym. However, to the human brain, the perception of time is more elastic. Time flies when you are having fun.

text: 1. See failure as a beginning. 2. Never stop learning. 3. Assume nothing, question everything. 4. Teach others what you know. 5. Analyze objectively. 6. Practice humility. 7. Respect constructive criticism. 8. Take initiative. 9. Give credit where it's due. 10. Love what you do.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: Young, ambitious talent often fall in the trap of believing that Negativity is Honesty & Cynicism is Intelligence. If you're down that rabbit hole you need a reality check. Authenticity is Honesty & Your Quality of Awareness is Intelligence. Dont let anyone tell you otherwise.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: Clarity is a tricky thing. Incredibly hard to come by. And when it comes, not long before its gone. It takes conscious effort and is a continuous process of discovery, peeling back layers in an ever changing world so full of information. But if mastered, one can move mountains

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3/ 2 loaded questions a. Will a million people pay for this? Not a large number but $30/month x 1M = $360M / Year. That's a $5B company right there. Think @onepeloton b. Can they keep out innovating their free counterparts and build lock-in? This is software after all.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @Dash3r911 Loved it. Read it years back. One of my top reads of all times.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 8/ I've always preferred watching > reading as a way to pick up new ideas though reading forces you to slow down, pay attention - a solid habit to build. It doesn't have to be perfect. Just focus on the small gains every day and let time do the rest.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 7/ That's approx 19-20 books. Assuming 400 pages per book x 19 / 365 = 20.82 pages per day. My guess is I'm either up or down 10-15%. On good days I've devoured half a book. On not so good days, 20 serves as a good minimum benchmark.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 6c/ The life and Times of Nikola Tesla: Arguably the world's most brilliant scientist yet history books rarely talk of him. An insight into his childhood, early years and stories behind some of his incredible inventions.//t.co/JEfdOVng9o

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 6b/ Cosmic Consciousness: A Study in the Evolution of the Human Mind. Incredibly deep and potent. Only for those insatiably curious about the mind and it's historical development.//t.co/BwpCpzZZpa

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 6a/ I've been yearning to get deeper into Ancient Hindu scriptures. Last year, I picked up an english translation of The Upanishads'. It's hard to articulate what the The Upanishads are in a tweet. Read more here -//t.co/0mcZn8C6ea//t.co/RJ95OPzCnT

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 6/ The next & final category is Deep Reads (books where I'm still just past half way)

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 5/ Next up is the Only Sci-Fi of 2018: Atlantis Gene Trilogy by A.G. Riddle. Genetic experiments, ancient conspiracies, mysteries of human evolution all in one thought provoking thriller.//t.co/KSGhh7HyPQ

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 4c/ The Art of War - Last of the re-reads. Summarizing this book is difficult. I found an interesting take on this book called The Art of War Visualized'. Think The Art of War in Graphs & Charts. Incredible find.//t.co/dfvHcrSb3s

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 4b/ Zen & the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance: The world is divided in 2 - The Classicals & Romantics. Classicals see the world through reason & laws. Romantics see the world through inspiration, creativity & intuition. At the intersection of both worlds is where magic exists.//t.co/Mq7N7kqGDQ

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 4a/ Eleven Rings: I'm not a basketball fan but Phill's a legend in the sport & his style is inspiring. Zen + Coach + Winning. Oneness is not something you can turn on with a switch. You need to create the right environment for it to grow, then nurture it carefully every day.//t.co/dIn29gmKTG

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 4/ Next up: Re-Reads of 2018. Some of my all time favorites.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3g/ Stealing Fire - The cover says it all. A deep insight into the potential of the human brain.//t.co/kYIKhCjz2o

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3f/ Sapiens - Finally got to this one. I can Imagine I'll re-read this in 2019.//t.co/rgNhsIfQDs

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3e/ Atomic Habits: Habits are systems like everything else. They can be influenced and changed. Excellent articulation by @jamesclear. A must read for those obsessed with their own productivity.//t.co/Jm4W6u89f4

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3d/ Principles by Ray Dalio - One of the best of 2018. Get Shit Done in Life & Work in a Systematic Way. @ray articulates his principles so clearly that it's hard not to grasp them. There's a lot of them. It's a deep one.//t.co/ijEo5sovo3

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3c/ Shoe Dog - In the beginner's mind there are many possibilities, but in the experts there are only a few - The book starts with this quote, one of my favourites. Excellent biography about the Creator of Nike.//t.co/JnyorDqrYA

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3b/ Total Competition - Think Art of War applied to Winning in @F1 . Goes behind scenes and into the mind of Ross Brawn, the man behind Schumacher's success on Strategy in F1 and operating a F1 team in the high pressure environment. For true F1 lovers.//t.co/dbLI391vBS

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3a/ Quirky - A collection of stories of some of the world's most breakthrough innovations and the innovators behind them - Tesla, Edison, Curie & more.//t.co/QTtwFQ49v6

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3/ The second category is Books that I found Incredibly Insightful. Some work, some play, some about life, some about all of them & more.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 2f/ Measure What Matters - One of my top 2018 reads. Can't thank @johndoerr enough for writing this. We tried OKRs in 2015 with little luck. In 2018 using this as our guide, we re-shaped how we do goal setting at @hikeapp. Gamechanger.//t.co/zKX44bzoFG

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 2e/ High Growth Handbook - One of those incredibly useful books that popped out of nowhere! A must read especially for first-time Founder/CEOs.Think of it a series of mini-Handbooks from word's top Founders, CEOs & Investors put together in one book. Thank you @eladgil!//t.co/t9sA5sHF3I

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 2d/ Creative Selection by @kocienda - An insight into Apple's incredible Demo culture and story behind how the iPhone's first keyboard was born. For all you aspiring rockstar engineers out there building experiences for consumers, THIS is a must read.//t.co/sbt56gh2wp

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 2c/ Blitzscaling - A quick one but insightful. @reidhoffman summarizes his book best in his tweets here -//t.co/pbT6eGqlYf. Highlight for me: Throw all typical management stuff out of the window. Speed > Perfection.//t.co/WN4l9QDgKU

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 2b/ Dream Teams by @shanesnow - I found this one on Twitter, I forget where and when. Loved every bit of it. Humorous & insightful. These images make me laugh everytime I see them. The core of the book: Diversity + Open-Mindedness = Super Teams. Highly recommended.//t.co/8VeSxknQVH

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 2a/ Powerful - Just in the way we have Strategy for Business, we must define Strategy for How We Work. Trust @pattymccord1 to articulate things so well :). We've been fortunate to have her as a close advisor @hikeapp. This is for those who care about building great culture.//t.co/W4jIOJS6LI

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 2/ The first category is Founder Reads. Books highly recommended for Founder & CEOs.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal

text: 5/ This is important, given Clarity and Alignment both have significant entropy given how fast things evolve. Motivation usually isn't the issue, it's usually a lack of Clarity that doesn't allow teams to get the best out of themselves.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 4/ Still extremely important for teams to come together. A lot of whiteboard catch ups tend to happen organically. On top of that 1:1s & functional catch ups continue to keep teams aligned.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: 3/ Result? It has significantly increased Productivity. Very few agenda-less meetings. A lot less context switching. This gives teams more room to focus on 'Real Work' and be In the Zone' more often.

text: When you drop ego, you can have great fun because you are no longer taking anything personally. You are a detached observer which has a peculiar joy of its own. Ego is a source of great tension. Egoistic people are anxious, self defensive and uptight. Drop the ego and chill out

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: Start living in discomfort. Gradually increase it little by little, and you will steadily grow. If you want sudden growth, deluge yourself in great discomfort and do not retreat from it. The more discomfort you are willing to bear, the more you can grow.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: Your idea of health is narrow. Expand it to include mental and emotional health. Your food intake is not limited to physical substances. It also includes intellectual and emotional impressions you receive. Right food for the soul is as important as right bodily nutrition.

text: What's actually amazing about this accident is that a Model S hit a fire truck at 60mph and the driver only broke an ankle. An impact at that speed usually results in severe injury or death.

text: @hikeapp launches Total, which is the company's version of Android which works without data using USSD. Smartphones that come loaded with TOTAL have single login using just the phone number, access to Hike ecosystem of apps like messaging, news, horoscopes, wallet @kavinbm//t.co/5IdUhQSSwm

text: And that's a wrap! Thanks to everyone who joined us, and for those just in- Total built by Hike is a refined version of Android to bring the next billion people onto data. You can find out all about it here://t.co/JDyskIZ7BU//t.co/mPDQBW6YAm

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: On TOTAL Built By Hike, users can also buy data sachets starting as low as Rs. 1 for rich format experiences like images and videos.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: Ranging between less than 100 KB to 1 MB, services on TOTAL Built By Hike also ensure a lightweight footprint on your device so users don't ever have to worry about their phone running out of space!

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: Log in using just your phone number to TOTAL Built By Hike to use all services like Messaging, News, Horoscope, Recharge, Wallet, Cricket Scores and Rail information. Switch on your phone and you're ready to go in just a couple of taps!//t.co/qh2wwVcHk6

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @nixxin @SatanAtWink @MeghaVishwanath When you push the boundaries, some things work and some don't. Talk-time now replicated nationally.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @SatanAtWink @nixxin @MeghaVishwanath @hikeapp is a perfect example despite FB being zero rated and market flooded with WA packs

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @SatanAtWink @nixxin @MeghaVishwanath Small players have enough of a market to grow if the product is great

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @SatanAtWink @nixxin @MeghaVishwanath then well the product likely sucks.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @SatanAtWink @nixxin @MeghaVishwanath Zero will not matter. That's the size of a small country. If a product can't penetrate that,

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @SatanAtWink @nixxin @MeghaVishwanath Half it further = 7.5M users across India (3.75%). These are consumers/early adopters to whom

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @SatanAtWink @nixxin @MeghaVishwanath = 15M. These are people who have gone out of their way to buy a data pack.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @SatanAtWink @nixxin @MeghaVishwanath That argument is flawed. 200M Internet Users. 15% on Full Data Packs = 30M. Half it to be conservative

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @SatanAtWink @nixxin @MeghaVishwanath the ecosystem. It's a big problem

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @SatanAtWink @nixxin @MeghaVishwanath Having an app on the store and being forced not to monetize because of compliance is extremely bad for

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @SatanAtWink @nixxin @MeghaVishwanath Really?I can plug in my pay gateway tom but I'm not allowed to despite App Stores not having their own

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @SatanAtWink @nixxin @MeghaVishwanath Is being forced to use their non existent payment gateways (India) a good standard?

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @nixxin @MeghaVishwanath Vendors isn't apt because they serve the telco, apps don't. Difference here is pipe and product are de-coupled

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @nixxin @MeghaVishwanath Id agree with that relatively speaking. Apple/Google have thrown fair share of apps off the store for not complying

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @MeghaVishwanath Vendors is a traditional word and actually the wrong metaphor. Are we vendors to the App Stores? #ios #android #windows

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @MeghaVishwanath Vendors is a traditional word and actually the wrong metaphor. Are we vendors to the App Stores? #ios #android #windows

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal

text: @vijayanands Not the apt comparison. Subsidizing goods vs A platform that enables. I still believe details need to be thought through

text: @vijayanands It takes some big to make that change happen. New opportunities. #Internet

text: @vijayanands Ppl aren't just going to wake up one day and start magically earning more.

text: @vijayanands In a big way. You'll be surprised at how many people use messaging in parts of this country. It's insightful.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @vijayanands And it's not going to be solved with today's models.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @vijayanands I think it's important not to lose sight of the fact that connectivity for the next few billion is a big problem to be solved

text: @kanchankumar anything of value. Is A0 the answer? I'm not sure but I won't be surprised that with time, a model emerges that will work 2/n

text: @kanchankumar Almost all data globally shows that sampling the internet leads to a wider adoption of the internet. That's true with 1/n

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @nixxin 2/2 Airtel Zero = An open platform to allow any developer to buy data in bulk and make their service free of cost.

name: Kavin Bharti Mittal
text: @nixxin 1/2 Zero Rating = Telco choice. Telco chooses which app will be free of cost. It's not great for the ecosystem.
